question.text: Although much CO<sub>2</sub> is carried in blood, bloods does not become acidic because

options.text: It is absorbed by the leucocytes
Blood buffers play an important role in CO<sub>2</sub> transport.
It combines with water to from carbonic acid which is neutralized by NaCO<sub>3</sub>
It is continuously diffused through tissues and is not allowed to accumulate

solution.text: CO<sub>2</sub> enters RBC and reacts with water to form carbonic acid. Carbonic acid dissociates to form bicarbonate and hydrogen ions. Some bicarbonate ions are transported in erythrocytes, while some diffuse into the blood plasma. Exit of bicarbonate ions changes the ionic balance between the plasma and erythrocytes. To restore this balance, chloride ions diffuse from plasma into erythrocytes. Due to this, the pH of blood is maintained.
